office_hours: Available in person or virtually over Microsoft Teams
SLOs:
Learning Objectives
Apply protocols for an effective job search;Gain insight into a possible career path of interest while learning about the industry in;which the organization resides, organizational structure, and roles and responsibilities within that structure;Understand of how coursework ties to professional careers of interest;Develop professional connections and identify a strategy for maintaining those connections;Reflection on the internship experiences;Ability to articulate what was learned and how it will be applied to your professional career goals;Identification of professions that may be of interest as a result of this experience;Identification of additional skills that will need to be developed to ensure career readiness;This might include learning a new technology, developing a broader network, additional coursework, etc.
workload: minimum 45 hours of course work per credit, which includes 40 hours of onsite work hours per credit
grading_procedures_title: GRADING AND EVALUATION OF STUDENT WORK
deadline_expectations_title: Expectations regarding assignment deadlines, late, or missing work
grading_process: 1. Completion of weekly work log for the minimal required work hours. Logs must be submitted weekly (of each work week) during your internship (20%) 2. Final project report (25%) 3. In-class progress presentations and submission of slide decks and summary for the presentation. (20%) 4. Class Participation. (35%). a. Attendance at scheduled class meetings b. Request to join in UNHM COMPTECH online LinkedIn group https://www.linkedin.com/groups/4485737/ c. Participation of all class discussions, peer meetups and group activities recorded in weekly work logs AND earn at least 75% for your final report grade.

workload: minimum of 180 hours of total student work
grading_process: Grading Policy: Assignments Homework 30% Projects 70%

SLOs:
Learning Objectives
List and describe principles and processes of cultural anthropology that challenge ethnocentricity; Present the findings from research in a clear and concise manner; Analyze and evaluate various research, theories and theorists from major anthropological schools of thought. Demonstrate critical thinking skills (in reading, writing, and discussion) and communication skills in assimilating and synthesizing the information of the course.
workload: minimum 3 hours of engaged time per week per credit over a 15-week semester
grading_process: Course Grading System: Reflective Papers (4) 15% Proposal 15% Research Paper 30% Midterm Exam 20% Final Exam 20% Total 100% Percent Grade Grade Points Level of Achievement

preferred_contact_method: Discussion board 'Course Questions' (for course-related questions); Email (for private matters)
SLOs:
Learning Objectives
Identify common technological and organizational measures for cybersecurity (focus: detection concepts and organizational relationships); Explain and give examples of the roles of best practices and standards in the design and implementation of such security measures; Explain the functional and organizational advantages and disadvantages of these measures, including impacts from their interaction; Assess the limitations of these security measures in the contexts of organizational change and dynamic threats, flawed technology, and flawed organizational policies and practices; Translate lessons learned from incidents into recommendations for cybersecurity planning and preparedness for better detection.
workload: expected to involve a minimum of 135 hours

SLOs:
Learning Objectives
Situate cybersecurity incident response and investigation within an organization's overall incident response policies and processes; Identify rules and best practices for reporting or otherwise communicating information about cybersecurity events and incidents; Identify concepts and methods for effective containment and mitigation of cybersecurity incidents; Articulate the roles of common tools and techniques for investigating and analyzing cybersecurity incidents; Explain and give examples of the differing mandates and priorities in the communities of interest for incident response and investigation (e.g., CERTs and CSIRTs, law enforcement agencies, regulators, vendors, intelligence community, etc.).

order to receive a grade.
• Completion of weekly work log for the minimal required work hours. Logs must be
submitted weekly (of each work week) during your internship (20%)
• Final project report (25%)

presentation. (20%)

a. Attendance at scheduled class meetings
b. Request to join in UNHM COMPTECH online LinkedIn group
https://www.linkedin.com/groups/4485737/
c. Participation of all class discussions, peer meetups and group activities
recorded in weekly work logs, OR you fail to earn minimal 75% for your final report grade.

Work Logs – (20% of grade)
First log due by 11:59 pm on Sunday, Sept 11 (to reflect 2 weeks of work/research activity)
Subsequent logs are due weekly, by 11:59 pm on Sunday for the prior week
In Class Presentations – (25% of grade) Your presentation/slides and reflection paper must be uploaded by noon on Friday following each class (Sept 2, Sept 9, Oct 14, Nov 25 and Dec 9)
Final Report – (25% of grade) Due by noon on Friday, December 9
Class Attendance (15% of grade)
Participation – (15% of grade) Required at each class, including questions for presenters; see MyCourse Assignments for Discussion posting requirements and due dates (9/16, 10/7, 11/11, 12/2 and 12/7).
REMINDER: You need to meet the 150 hours requirement and earn at least 75% on the Final Report to pass the class, in addition to earning points on other assignments (presentations and participation, etc).

Grading:
10% Participation
Undergrad: 10 points general participation
Grad: Wiki textbook work 10 points
48% Homework
There will be 4 assignments at 8, 8, 12 and 12+8 points respectively
20% Projects
Language Project: develop programming language, 6% grammar/14% implement
22% Exam
A final exam

Homework: 30% - Assigned weekly. All homework assignments are individual assignments. Each assignment includes 2-5 open-ended questions to review past week's material. Discussions: 20% - Assigned several times. Students participate in problem solving activities through online discussion. Requirements for the full credit: at least one discussion post and at least two replies to peer students. Midterm Exam: 20% - Take-home exam to be scheduled. Includes multiple choice questions and open-ended questions. Open notes. No collaboration is allowed while taking the examination. Final project: COMP730 - 30%, COMP830 - 20% - Group project (2-3 students in a team). You will be asked to develop an app of your choice. Project requirements: to be announced. Each team will give a presentation in the last class meeting. Individual Final Project: 10% COMP830 only - You will develop a solution to a software design problem. Project requirements: to be announced.

Final grade will be calculated based on the following weights: Participation 5%, Lab reports 15%, Assessments 30%, Individual project 15%, Team project 35%. Letter Grade Determination - The minimum cutoffs for the letter grades are shown in the table below. For example, if you earn 90%, you will get an A-. If you earn 89%, the letter grade is B+.

SLOs:
Learning Objectives
Situate cybersecurity incident response and investigation within an organization's overall incident response policies and processes; Identify rules and best practices for reporting or otherwise communicating information about cybersecurity events and incidents; Identify concepts and methods for effective containment and mitigation of cybersecurity incidents; Articulate the roles of common tools and techniques for investigating and analyzing cybersecurity incidents; Explain and give examples of the differing mandates and priorities in the communities of interest for incident response and investigation (e.g., CERTs and CSIRTs, law enforcement agencies, regulators, vendors, intelligence community, etc.)

filename: Exploring NH Forests, Drawing to Discover the Tree Community.pdf
SLOs:
Student Learning Outcomes
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
● Understand and appreciate art and its historical role in observational science
● Demonstrate foundational drawing skills such as line, value, form, perspective and composition
● Identify common New Hampshire tree species and their roles within forest communities
● Apply and explain the ecological principles that govern forest dynamics, including species
interactions, succession and forest biodiversity
● Produce a written and illustrated report that integrates ecological research, field observations
